content: Added cover art.

Looks easy but just challenging enough to make your brain thinking. Nice Job!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle

In "Tie - Followed", there is nothing in the problem statement that explains how to order user1 and user3...

Otherwise I have made a solution that passes all other testcases. Considering the input comes in no particular order, maintaining the order in the input does not make sense. The only other thing I can think of is to sort alphabetically OR numerically based on the number in the username since you state that the username has a number... Please resolve this and reply so I can approve the puzzle.

Great work!

I can't wait for it to be approved ! 
how can i help you approve it .....
Nice one!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and easy ! 
A good way for beginners to work on sorting.
Approved :)

After I see the examples, I understand, but initially this phrase is confusing:

"Comments contain | characters"

I thought "does she mean 1 character?"

Perhaps you could rephrase with "There are n comment-objects given to you in random order.  Each comment-object contains comment data (name, date, likes, priority), separated by a | "

Very Proffessional !
I Think It's a very good back-end project to show to your Interviewer ! it's simple on thinking but complex on coding !
sometimes simple ideas are complex to program/code and complex ideas are simple to program/code .....
While Reading your problem i had the idea that maybe i could share my work as puzzles here so other programmers that code here for fun help me code it before deadline.
Thank You So Much  I Love it

Maybe add the content of the comments ?
Not sure if it is desirable but it could add a bit more fun ?

You can use tools like http://www.randomyoutubecomment.com/ if you don't want to come up with comments on your own.

What do you think ?

Goal section
* Suggest some minor changes:
   â€¢ "gonna" â†’ "going to"
   â€¢ "." after "24-hour format"
   â€¢ "appear first" â†’ "appears first"
   â€¢ "it's priority" (pinned) â†’ "its priority"
   â€¢ "it's priority" (followed) â†’ "their priority"
   â€¢ "1<" â†’ "more than 1"
   â€¢ "they would appear" â†’ "the comments appear"
   â€¢ "in terms of" â†’ "ordered by"
   â€¢ "it's replies" â†’ "its replies"

* I don't understand what you mean by "Priorities may stack"... Each comment can have only 1 priority...?

* I don't understand this sentence:
"And the same goes for replies, if a reply is moved, the reply appears above all the other replies that are below it in the same comment."
1. As you have written in the previous sentence, once the order of the parent comments have been determined, the related replies will be moved together.
2. As one of the constraints states that there are not nested replies, my understanding is that the next step would be to sort the related replies based on priority/likes/date.
3. If the above is true, there won't be a case where replies have to be moved based on other replies, and there isn't such a thing as "reply above other replies", as they are just sorted based on the criteria?
4. If I have missed what you mean, would you please explain and show me an example (e.g. which test/validator is the explanation applicable to)?

Thanks.

Thanks, I will edit all of them once I am on my PC

And for your question, what I meant is when the parent comment is moved (changed in sorting), its replies will also move with it. it seems obvious so maybe me stating that is pointless (because I already stated that the replies are under the comment it belongs to previously.) 

And replies will also be sorted as comments do, tests 6 and 5 check for that.
I like the idea, but the content wouldn't be relevant and kinda time consuming for unnecessary input. so I thought of just giving the input needed for sorting. Thanks for the feedback.
Thanks for the nice feedback!

Indeed sounds better, just done it, thank you.

P.S. I am a guy, misleading pfp ðŸ˜…
also can you help me , my codes always get the error 'too much time to compile '

I explained it now in the statement, and modified the testcase's validator to have an actual tie.

Even I am unaware of how my program is sorting it, because I specified the key of sorting, and it didn't include the name in it, so I am assuming python doesn't modify user1 and user3 and just keeps them in their order.

Thanks for the feedback, and if you feel like the tie case all over is unnecessary, please let me know.
Looking good, thank you!
(This is me on a different account) I donâ€™t think it matters just specify clearly that ties are broken alphabetically or that there are no ties itâ€™s fine, just be very clear about it either way.
me here verifying about comment. Congrats on getting your puzzle approved!
